title: Wildlife of Malaysia
text:
The wildlife of Malaysia is diverse, with <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> being a <a href="Megadiverse%20countries">megadiverse country</a>. Most of the country is covered in <a href="rainforest">rainforest</a>, which hosts a huge <a href="biodiversity">diversity</a> of plant and animal species. There are approximately 361 mammal species, 694 <a href="%23Birds">bird</a> species, 250 reptile species, and 150 frog species found in Malaysia. Its large marine territory also holds a great diversity of life, with the country's coastal waters comprising part of the <a href="Coral%20Triangle">Coral Triangle</a>.
Terrestrial fauna.
Malaysia is estimated to contain 20% of the world's animal species, and includes some of the most biodiverse areas on the planet. High levels of endemism are found in the diverse forests of Malaysian Borneo's mountains, as populations are isolated from each other by lowland forest.
Mammals.
There are about 361 mammal species in Malaysia. <a href="Peninsular%20Malaysia">Peninsular Malaysia</a> holds four <a href="big%20cat">big cat</a>s: the <a href="Indochinese%20tiger">Indochinese tiger</a>, the <a href="Malayan%20tiger">Malayan tiger</a>, the <a href="Indochinese%20leopard">Indochinese leopard</a> and also the <a href="clouded%20leopard">clouded leopard</a>. Another major predator is the <a href="sunbear">sunbear</a>. Large prey exists, such as the <a href="Sumatran%20rhinoceros">Sumatran rhinoceros</a>, the <a href="Malayan%20tapir">Malayan tapir</a>, <a href="mouse%20deer">mouse deer</a>, <a href="barking%20deer">barking deer</a>, <a href="sambar%20deer">sambar deer</a>, <a href="wild%20boar">wild boar</a>, and <a href="Bornean%20bearded%20pig">Bornean bearded pig</a>s.
<a href="Gaur">Gaur</a>s and <a href="Asian%20elephant">Asian elephant</a>s can also be found. Lowland animals such as these also can be found at higher altitudes, along with animals specialised for mountain living, such as <a href="siamang%20gibbon">siamang gibbon</a>s, <a href="red%20squirrel">red squirrel</a>s, and <a href="lesser%20moon%20rat">lesser moon rat</a>s. <a href="East%20Malaysia">East Malaysia</a> lacks the tigers of the Peninsula, leaving clouded leopards, sunbears, and <a href="Otter%20civet">Sunda otter civet</a>s as the primary predators. <a href="Rhinoceros">Rhinoceros</a>es and <a href="elephant">elephant</a>s are also found there, along with <a href="Bornean%20orangutan">Bornean orangutan</a>s, <a href="M%C3%BCller%27s%20Bornean%20gibbon">Mueller's gibbons</a>, <a href="macaques">macaques</a>, <a href="proboscis%20monkey">proboscis monkey</a>s, <a href="silvered%20leaf%20monkey">silvered leaf monkey</a>s, <a href="langur">langur</a>s, and <a href="slow%20loris">slow loris</a>es.
<a href="Bornean%20ferret-badger">Kinabalu ferret-badger</a>s, <a href="Black%20shrew">Kinabalu black shrew</a>s, <a href="Hose%27s%20palm%20civet">Hose's palm civet</a>s, and <a href="Brooke%27s%20squirrel">Brooke's tree squirrel</a>s are endemic to the mountains of Borneo. Other small mammals include <a href="mongoose">mongoose</a>s and <a href="Large%20bamboo%20rat">giant rats</a>. 11,300 orangutans are found in East Malaysia. Other ape species include the <a href="white-handed%20gibbon">white-handed gibbon</a> and the <a href="siamang">siamang</a>. Malaysia has 10 monkey species, divided between <a href="langurs">langurs</a> and <a href="macaques">macaques</a>. Proboscis monkeys, the world's largest monkey, are a langur species endemic to Borneo. Macaque species include the <a href="crab-eating%20macaque">crab-eating macaque</a> and the <a href="Southern%20pig-tailed%20macaque">pig-tailed macaque</a>.
The Malayan tiger, a close relative of the Indochinese tiger, is endemic to the Malay peninsula with a remaining population of about 300 (250-340). Small cats such as the <a href="bay%20cat">bay cat</a> and various civet cats are also found. 1200 Asian elephants exist on the Peninsula, with another population existing in East Malaysia. The world's largest cattle species, the <a href="seladang">seladang</a>, is found in Malaysia. Fruit bats are also found throughout the country, with a high concentration in the <a href="Mulu%20Caves">Mulu Caves</a>.
Birds.
677 species of <a href="birds">birds</a> have been recorded just on the peninsula, with 794 recorded for the whole of Malaysia. A few are endemic to the mountains of the peninsula, such as the <a href="Malayan%20Whistling-Thrush">Malayan Whistling-Thrush</a>. Bornean forests show high levels of endemism among bird species, with 38 species found nowhere else. <a href="Black-browed%20babbler">Black-browed babbler</a>s and <a href="white-crowned%20shama">white-crowned shama</a>s are found only in these forests. Large numbers of <a href="hornbill">hornbill</a>s, <a href="woodpecker">woodpecker</a>s, and <a href="pitta">pitta</a>s such as the <a href="mangrove%20pitta">mangrove pitta</a> are also present.
Other species are found isolated on mountains, such as <a href="golden-naped%20barbet">golden-naped barbet</a>s, <a href="spot-necked%20bulbul">spot-necked bulbul</a>s, and <a href="mountain%20serpent-eagle">mountain serpent-eagle</a>s. <a href="Bulbul">Bulbul</a>s, <a href="starling">starling</a>s, and <a href="house%20swift">house swift</a>s can be found in urban areas. <a href="Crested%20serpent-eagle">Crested serpent-eagle</a>s and <a href="kingfisher">kingfisher</a>s can be found. There are nine species of hornbill in Malaysia, the most common of which is the <a href="Oriental%20pied%20hornbill">Oriental pied hornbill</a>. At from head to tail is the largest hornbill, the <a href="great%20hornbill">great hornbill</a>, followed closely in size by the <a href="rhinoceros%20hornbill">rhinoceros hornbill</a> of Borneo. The <a href="Grey-headed%20fish%20eagle">fish eagle</a> and <a href="brahminy%20kite">brahminy kite</a> are the most common birds of prey. <a href="Storm%27s%20stork">Storm's stork</a> and the <a href="Oriental%20darter">Oriental darter</a> can be found in wetlands.
Reptiles.
250 reptile species have been recorded, with about 150 species of snakes and 80 species of lizards. Only 16 of the land snakes are venomous. Notable among these are the <a href="Malayan%20pit%20viper">Malayan pit viper</a>, <a href="king%20cobra">king cobra</a>s, <a href="Dumeril%27s%20monitor">Dumeril's monitor</a>s, <a href="Malay%20water%20monitor">Malay water monitor</a>s, and <a href="estuarine%20crocodile">estuarine crocodile</a>s. The king cobra is the deadliest snake found, but it is rarely encountered. The <a href="reticulated%20python">reticulated python</a> is said to grow up to in length. <a href="Monitor%20lizard">Monitor lizard</a>s, almost in length, are found in both halves of the country.
Other snake species include the <a href="paradise%20tree%20snake">paradise tree snake</a> and <a href="Wagler%27s%20pit%20viper">Wagler's pit viper</a>. Estuarine crocodiles can grow up to in length. Their smaller relative, the <a href="Malayan%20false%20gharial">Malayan false gharial</a>, can also be found. <a href="Draco%20%28genus%29">Flying lizards</a> can also be found.
There are about 150 species of frog in Malaysia. Freshwater fish include the rare <a href="Asian%20arawana">Asian arawana</a>, along with <a href="marbled%20goby">marbled goby</a>, <a href="Harlequin%20rasbora">harlequin</a>s, and <a href="tiger%20barb">tiger barb</a>s.
Insects.
Malaysia has thousands of insect species, with more being discovered every year. Butterfly species include <a href="Rajah%20Brooke%27s%20birdwing">Rajah Brooke's birdwing</a>, while moth species include the <a href="Atlas%20moth">Atlas moth</a>. The largest beetle found is the <a href="rhinoceros%20beetle">rhinoceros beetle</a>. Other large insects include the <a href="giant%20stick%20insect">giant stick insect</a>, which can grow as long as a human forearm, the <a href="empress%20cicada">empress cicada</a>, with a wingspan of , and the long <a href="giant%20ant">giant ant</a>. Other insects include <a href="Greater%20banded%20hornet">banded hornet</a>s, <a href="fire%20ant">fire ant</a>s, <a href="giant%20honey%20bee">giant honey bee</a>s, and <a href="weaver%20ant">weaver ant</a>s. Many <a href="scorpion">scorpion</a>s can also be found.
Terrestrial flora.
About two thirds of Malaysia is covered in forest which is believed to be 130 million years old. It is composed of a variety of types, although they are mainly <a href="Dipterocarpaceae">dipterocarp</a> forests. Dipterocarps can grow to about tall. Lowland forest occurs below , and formerly East Malaysia was covered in <a href="Borneo%20lowland%20rain%20forests">such rainforest</a>, which is supported by its hot wet climate. There are around 14,500 species of flowering plants and trees.
Besides rainforests, there are over of mangroves in Malaysia, and a large amount of peat forest. Coastal land of the peninsula is fringed by <a href="mangroves">mangroves</a>, which cause sediment build up resulting in peat bogs. These provide a base for plants that can tolerate the conditions. The peat forests of coastal Malaysia provide an important habitat for waterbirds and fish. The dipterocarps that occur in the peat forest obscure the ground, limiting ground vegetation. At higher altitudes, oaks, chestnuts, and rhododendrons replace dipterocarps.
There are an estimated 8,500 species of <a href="vascular%20plant">vascular plant</a>s in Peninsular Malaysia, with another 15,000 in the East. The forests of East Malaysia are estimated to be the habitat of around 2,000 tree species, and are one of the most biodiverse areas in the world, with 240 different species of trees every hectare. Further inland, <a href="heath%20forest">heath forest</a>s are present. These forests host many members of the genus "<a href="Rafflesia">Rafflesia</a>", the largest flowers in the world, with a maximum diameter of . They also contain large numbers of <a href="carnivorous%20plants">carnivorous plants</a>, such as <a href="pitcher%20plant">pitcher plant</a>s, <a href="bladderworts">bladderworts</a>, <a href="sundew">sundew</a>s, and <a href="ant-house%20plant">ant-house plant</a>s.
Some parts of the forest have shown promise for use in medicine. In 1990, a stand of trees showed promise to be able to be used to stop the spread of a strain of <a href="Human%20Immunodeficiency%20Virus">Human Immunodeficiency Virus</a>, but was cut down before more samples could be taken. Promise has been shown in fighting <a href="Malaria">Malaria</a>.
Marine life.
Malaysia's <a href="exclusive%20economic%20zone">exclusive economic zone</a> is 1.5 times larger than its land area, and some of its waters are in the <a href="Coral%20Triangle">Coral Triangle</a>, a biodiversity hotspot. The waters around <a href="Sipadan%20island">Sipadan island</a> are the most biodiverse in the world. Bordering East Malaysia, the <a href="Sulu%20Sea">Sulu Sea</a> is a biodiversity hotspot, with around 600 coral species and 1200 fish species. Five species of <a href="sea%20turtle">sea turtle</a>s inhabit the area, along with 20 species of <a href="sea%20snake">sea snake</a>. The <a href="dugong">dugong</a> is found around Sabah and in the <a href="Strait%20of%20Johor">Strait of Johor</a>.
Sharks present include <a href="whale%20shark">whale shark</a>s, <a href="hammerhead%20shark">hammerhead shark</a>s, and <a href="reef%20shark">reef shark</a>s. Game fish such as the <a href="Makaira">Blue marlin</a> and <a href="tuna">tuna</a> are often found, along with reef fish such as <a href="barracuda">barracuda</a>, <a href="bigeye%20trevally">bigeye trevally</a>, <a href="bump-head%20parrotfish">bump-head parrotfish</a>, <a href="grouper">grouper</a>, and <a href="Scorpaenidae">scorpionfish</a>. <a href="Manta%20ray">Manta ray</a>s can be found.
Environmental issues and countermeasures.
With Malaysia's wildlife being some of the most diverse on earth, and it being a <a href="Megadiverse%20countries">megadiverse country</a>, the Malaysian government is interested in protecting it. The government aims to balance <a href="economic%20growth">economic growth</a> with <a href="environmental%20protection">environmental protection</a>, but has been accused of favouring "<a href="big%20business">big business</a>" over the environment. Smoke haze from Indonesia occasionally causes problems further north, and fires caused by forest burning in 1997 obscured large parts of <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and <a href="Australasia">Australasia</a> in smog.
At current rates of <a href="forest%20loss">forest lost</a>, the rainforests will likely disappear within a generation. Over 80% of <a href="Sarawak">Sarawak</a> has been cleared, and this clearing has caused animals traditionally in lowland forest to retreat into the <a href="Borneo%20montane%20rain%20forests">upland rain forests</a> inland. Logging and cultivation practices have devastated <a href="tree%20cover">tree cover</a>, causing severe <a href="environmental%20degradation">environmental degradation</a> in the country. Floods in East Malaysia have been worsened by the loss of trees, and over 60% of the peninsula's forest has been cleared. With current rates of deforestation, the forests are predicted to be extinct by 2020. From 2000 to 2019, Sabah lost 1.60Mha, or 24%, of its tree cover. 51% of this loss came from <a href="Tongod">Tongod</a>, <a href="Beluran">Beluran</a>, <a href="Tawau">Tawau</a>, and <a href="Kinabatangan">Kinabatangan</a>. In the same period, Sarawak lost 2.96Mha or 25% of its tree cover. Together, they made up 56% of Malaysia's 8.12Mha (28%) loss in tree cover during that period.
<a href="Social%20and%20environmental%20impact%20of%20palm%20oil%23Deforestation">Deforestation</a> is a major problem for fauna such as tigers, as the forest is cut to make room for plantations, mostly for palm oil and other cash crops. The orangutan population has dropped by 40% in the last 20 years. Hunting has also been an issue. Animals such as the Asian elephant have been forced out of their habitat due to its loss, often leading them to starve. Once so common that complaints existed of them trampling people's gardens, Sumatran rhinoceroses are likely to become extinct in Malaysia. Hornbills are steadily declining in numbers. Most remaining forest is found inside national parks.
Habitat destruction has proved a threat for marine life. <a href="Illegal%20fishing">Illegal fishing</a> is another major threat. In Sabah alone, almost 3000 turtles are killed as <a href="by-catch">by-catch</a> per year. Illegal fishing methods such as <a href="dynamite%20fishing">dynamite fishing</a> and poisoning have also depleted marine ecosystems. <a href="Leatherback%20turtle">Leatherback turtle</a> numbers have dropped by 98% since the 1950s. Turtle eggs are considered an aphrodisiac and remain a local delicacy, selling for around USD12 for 10. However, some communities that once regularly consumed turtle eggs now protect them, with hatching turtles becoming an ecotourism draw. <a href="Terengganu">Terengganu</a> outlaws the sale of leatherback turtle eggs. While licensed collection and sale of the eggs from other species is still legal, the state has pledged to extend the ban on sale to all turtle species.
<a href="Overconsumption">Overconsumption</a> and the use of animal parts for profit has also endangered marine life, as well as tigers, whose meat can be found in restaurants in Kuala Lumpur. Tigers received official protection in 1976, when they numbered a mere 300. Marine life is also detrimentally affected by uncontrolled tourism. Shoreline erosion in places has reached a year.
Pollution was the impetus for the creation of the Environmental Quality Act in 1974. Pollution has continued to increase, and punishment for violations has been limited in comparison to other crimes. In 2020, illegal chemical dumping into the water system caused water cuts to households in the <a href="Klang%20Valley">Klang Valley</a>, in which the capital <a href="Kuala%20Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a> is situated.
Most environmental regulation falls under the control of the states. Some state governments are now trying to counter the environmental impact and pollution created by deforestation; Sabah has developed sustainable forest reserves, and the government is trying to cut logging by 10% per year. 28 national parks have been created, the first in 1938 by the British. There are 23 on East Malaysia and 7 on the Peninsula. The Malaysian government is also trying to preserve marine life, creating a joint project with Indonesia and the Philippines to look after the Sulu Sea, as well as limiting tourism in areas such as Sipadan Island. Marine parks have banned fishing and motorised sports. To counter <a href="coastal%20erosion">coastal erosion</a>, the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Science%2C%20Technology%20and%20Innovation%20%28Malaysia%29">Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation</a> has installed <a href="artificial%20reef">artificial reef</a>s around the country's shores. These reefs are also intended to revive marine ecosystems. <a href="Animal%20trafficking">Animal trafficking</a> is a large issue, and the Malaysian government is holding talks with the governments of Brunei and Indonesia to standardise anti-trafficking laws. The government aims to double the wild tiger population by 2020.
